p: The SAR study by Brice-Tutt et al. [ 8] studied the influence of the Phe residuesâ€™ stereochemistry in the macrocyclic tetrapeptide CJ-15,208 ( cyclo[Phe-D-Pro-Phe-Trp]), from the fungus Ctenomyces serratus, and its analogue [D-Trp]CJ-15,208 ( cyclo[Phe-D-Pro-Phe-D-Trp]) on opioid activity profiles. Unlike the parent peptides, KOR antagonism was exhibited by only one stereoisomer, while another isomer produced DOR antagonism. They identified the stereoisomer [D-Phe 1,3]CJ-15,208 as a potent antinociceptive after oral administration lacking respiratory depression and locomotor impairment and without preference or aversion in mice.
